elements.title: Progressive Value Visualization
elements.problem: Zella provided extensive information (location, schedule, budget, timeline) but received no visual representation of value in return. The call was entirely transactional without visual feedback showing her requirements being processed and matched to concrete options. This creates a visual void where commitment happens in darkness—the guest can't see their search taking shape, their filters being applied, or their needs being met. Visual hierarchy should show the guest what they're getting in exchange for what they're giving.
elements.solution: Create visual reciprocity through real-time visualization of guest input transforming into platform output. When guest provides location, immediately render map with matching properties. When guest sets schedule (Wed-Sat), show calendar visualization with their days highlighted and co-tenant days in complementary visual treatment. When guest sets budget, show price distribution graph with their range highlighted and similar guests' actual prices as data points. Use color to distinguish guest input (accent green) from platform response (warm neutrals with accent touches), creating clear visual exchange.

evidence.quote: Guests make escalating commitments but receive diminishing tangible value in return. The guest invested call time and information but left empty-handed.
evidence.insight: Visual design must make the value exchange visible and immediate. Each piece of guest data should trigger visible platform response within the same viewport.

evidence.quote: Every piece of information the guest provides must unlock an equivalent piece of information they receive, in real-time within the same interaction.
evidence.insight: Visual hierarchy must prioritize what guest receives (matching listings, validation) over what guest provides (forms, inputs). Use visual weight and color to make reciprocal value dominant.

evidence.quote: Agent asks for walking distance, guest provides detailed location requirements. Agent responds: 'I do have, uh, some vacations available' without showing anything.
evidence.insight: The absence of visual confirmation creates doubt. Guest needs to SEE the properties on a map, SEE the price ranges, SEE the availability—not just hear vague verbal acknowledgment.

spacing: md between input and visual response
new_tokens_needed: accent-gradient for visual emphasis on reciprocal value

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Accent green (#2d5a3d) provides 4.7:1 contrast on surface white. Data visualizations must use stroke width 2px minimum for visibility. Text labels 14px minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Visual response to guest input must be larger, more colorful, and more spatially prominent than the input itself. Use 60-40 ratio: 60% viewport shows what guest gets, 40% shows what guest provides. Left-to-right reading order: input left, response right.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm, not cold: Use warm off-white backgrounds (#f6f4f0) not stark white. Confident through clarity: Visual feedback should be instant and precise, not decorative. Trustworthy through real data: Show actual property photos, real price ranges, genuine availability—never placeholder content.

elements.title: Social Proof Micro-Portraits
elements.problem: Zella's journey had zero visual evidence of other guests. Cialdini's research shows social proof is most powerful when uncertainty is high, yet Split Lease provides no visual representation of similar guests who successfully completed the journey. Text testimonials alone are weak—faces, names, and specific outcomes create credibility. The split-lease model is inherently uncertain, making visual social proof essential for building confidence.
elements.solution: Embed small portrait photographs (48px circular avatars) of real guests at every uncertainty point, paired with their specific outcome in data-focused typography. Discovery: '1,200+ professionals found housing' with 4-5 overlapping guest avatars. Search: Show guest portrait with quote and outcome ('Maya, CCNY professor: Found Wed-Sat housing in 6 days, $105/night'). Listing evaluation: Host response rate shown with small portraits of guests who got responses. Use serif typography for guest names (personality, trust) and mono for data outcomes (precision, credibility). Portraits should feel candid and warm, not stock photo corporate.

evidence.quote: Not once during the call does the agent reference: other guests with similar needs, successful matches in the CCNY area, typical pricing for Wednesday-Saturday schedules, reviews of hosts or properties, testimonials from current split-lease residents.
evidence.insight: Visual absence of social proof creates vacuum of confidence. Portraits make social proof concrete and scannable—guest can assess similarity at a glance through visual cues (age, style, context).

evidence.quote: We are most influenced by the actions of others like us.
evidence.insight: Visual similarity assessment happens instantly through portraits. Guest can quickly determine 'does this person look like me?' which validates whether their path is relevant.

evidence.quote: Primary: Evidence from similar guests (photos, names, quotes, outcomes). Secondary: Aggregate statistics. Social proof must be people-first, not company-first.
evidence.insight: Visual hierarchy must lead with human faces, not numbers. 48px portrait is scannable but humanizing—large enough to register facial features and emotional warmth, small enough to not dominate.

new_tokens_needed: social-proof-highlight for emphasis on outcome numbers

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text. Guest names and outcomes must meet 4.5:1 contrast minimum. Portrait rings should be subtle (#e2dfd9) to avoid competing with faces. Quotes can be softer (#4a4640) as secondary supporting content.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Portraits lead the eye first (human faces draw attention), followed by data outcomes in mono (precision signals credibility), then supporting quotes last. Use spatial proximity: portrait + name + outcome should form tight visual cluster (24px total spacing) while quotes can float with more breathing room (40px).
elements.brand_alignment: Trustworthy, not corporate: Real guest photos with natural expressions, not staged corporate headshots. Premium-accessible: Typography mixing serif (approachable) and mono (precision) creates sophisticated but human feel. Warm through color: Surface-warm backgrounds and ink-soft quotes maintain warmth while staying professional.

elements.title: Active Commitment Chain Visualization
elements.problem: The call ended with Zella in passive waiting mode ('I'll be in touch'). She has no visual record of her commitments and no visual path forward. Cialdini shows that written, visible commitments create stronger consistency pressure than verbal agreements. Without visual representation of the commitment chain (bid placed → call completed → requirements provided), the guest can't see their accumulating investment or feel the momentum toward completion.
elements.solution: Create persistent progress visualization showing all guest commitments as completed steps in a vertical timeline. Each commitment gets a checkmark icon (24px, accent green) with timestamp in mono font and action description in sans serif. Upcoming steps shown in muted colors (ink-ghost) with empty circle icons. Use vertical spatial progression (top = completed, middle = current, bottom = upcoming) to create visual sense of journey advancement. Current active step gets accent-light background treatment and slightly larger typography (18px vs 16px) for emphasis.

evidence.quote: The call ends with 'I'll be in touch' creating a commitment vacuum where the guest has no active role and commitment begins to decay immediately.
evidence.insight: Visual persistence combats decay. Timeline must remain visible across all pages as sidebar or header element, constantly reminding guest of their investment and showing clear next step.

evidence.quote: Written commitments are so effective because they require more work than verbal ones and can be shown to other people.
evidence.insight: Visual timeline makes commitments 'written' in a sense—they're recorded, visible, and persistent. Guest can screenshot and share, increasing commitment power.

evidence.quote: Show accumulating commitment chain before each new request: 'You've placed a bid, explored 8 properties, and favorited 2. Ready to create your first proposal?'
evidence.insight: Visual count badges (circular, 20px, mono font) on completed steps create quantified progress. '8 properties explored' feels more substantial than 'you browsed some listings.'

typography: sans 16px medium for current step title
sans 14px regular ink-ghost for future steps

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all active and completed text. Future steps in ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) provide 3.0:1 contrast—acceptable for inactive states. Checkmarks use accent green with 2px stroke for visibility. Timeline connector at least 2px width.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Current step dominates through size (18px title vs 16px for others), color intensity (full ink vs ink-ghost for future), and background treatment (accent-light panel vs transparent for others). Vertical reading order creates natural narrative of progress. Icons align left, text starts at consistent left margin 32px from icons.
elements.brand_alignment: Confident through clarity: Timeline creates unambiguous sense of progress and next action. Trustworthy through transparency: Guest sees exactly where they are and what's ahead. Warm through rounded icons (full radius circles) and gentle accent-light backgrounds rather than harsh borders.

elements.title: Complexity-Confidence Visual Pairing
elements.problem: The agent revealed complexity (matching timeline, co-tenant approval, pricing variability) without visual confidence-building. Zella heard abstract explanations but saw no data validation. When complexity is explained in text alone, it feels overwhelming. When paired with visual data showing successful outcomes, complexity becomes manageable challenge. Visual design must make predictable outcome ranges visible alongside complexity explanations.
elements.solution: Create side-by-side visual pairing: left panel shows complexity explanation (sans serif body text with icon), right panel shows confidence data visualization (bar chart, timeline distribution, success rate graphic). Use warm amber color (signal-warn) for complexity elements to acknowledge challenge without alarm, and accent green for confidence data to create visual relief. Example: Matching timeline explanation (left) paired with distribution graph showing 'Most Wed-Sat guests matched in 5-7 days' with histogram bars (right). Keep complexity text minimal (3-4 sentences max) and data visualization simple (single chart type, 3-5 data points).

evidence.quote: The agent progressively reveals complexity without corresponding confidence-building elements. Zella learns what's hard but not what makes it succeed.
evidence.insight: Visual pairing creates instant relief. Left side acknowledges challenge, right side validates it's solvable. Horizontal split creates natural 'problem-solution' reading pattern.

evidence.quote: Complexity + confidence pairing. Reveal complexity paired with confidence in same disclosure. Outcome validation first, complexity explanation second.
evidence.insight: Visual hierarchy must lead with confidence data (right side, larger, colorful) while complexity explanation supports (left side, smaller, neutral). Guest's eye drawn to success evidence first.

evidence.quote: Agent explains pricing complexity: 'if you need two nights and somebody needs five nights... we would have to go a little higher per night'
evidence.insight: Abstract verbal explanation creates anxiety. Visual range chart showing '$100-115/night regardless of configuration' creates concrete expectation and reduces uncertainty.

colors: signal-warn for complexity icons and accents
typography: sans 13px regular for data supporting text
spacing: xl between complexity and confidence panels
md within each panel for text sections
lg between section and next content block

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text. Signal-warn (#c17a28) provides 4.8:1 contrast on white. Complexity text in ink-soft (#4a4640) provides 7.5:1 contrast. Data visualizations use minimum 2px stroke width and accent green fill for visibility. Chart labels 14px minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Confidence panel (right) should be 55% viewport width vs complexity panel (left) 45%, creating visual bias toward solution. Confidence data uses accent color (eye-catching) while complexity uses signal-warn (acknowledging but not alarming). Vertical alignment: titles align across panels, creating visual cohesion while maintaining left-right distinction.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm through color choice: Signal-warn (amber) is warm and cautionary without being harsh like red. Confident through data transparency: Showing actual distribution graphs and success rates rather than vague reassurance. Trustworthy through balanced presentation: Not hiding complexity, but contextualizing it with real outcomes.

elements.title: Platform Comprehension Visual Primer
elements.problem: Zella registered and placed a bid without understanding the split-lease model—she thought she was speaking to a host with one property. Text explanations are easy to skip or misunderstand. Visual demonstration of the core concept (two guests, complementary schedules, shared cost) must happen before commitment actions are enabled. The visual must be interactive to confirm comprehension, not passive to allow glazing over.
elements.solution: Create interactive calendar visualization showing the split-schedule concept. Guest selects their desired days (visual: green accent highlighting on calendar grid), platform immediately shows complementary co-tenant days in contrasting warm neutral color. Below calendar, show cost split calculation with clear visual math: 'Full rent $2,400/month ÷ 2 guests = $1,200 each for your Wed-Sat days.' Use large, friendly typography (serif 24px for headline, sans 18px for body) and spacious layout (xl spacing) to avoid cognitive overwhelm. Interaction required: guest must click through 3 steps (select days, see cost split, confirm understanding) before bid button becomes enabled (accent green, full opacity vs disabled state at 50% opacity).

evidence.quote: Zella placed a bid and registered yet confuses 'Split Lease' with 'Straight Lease' and needs core concept explained from scratch.
evidence.insight: Text-only explanations get skipped. Interactive visual demonstration forces engagement and creates memorable mental model through doing, not reading.

evidence.quote: Use interactive visualization: guest selects their desired days, platform shows complementary co-tenant days visually. Require interaction with explanation before enabling bid button.
evidence.insight: Interaction creates commitment through participation. Guest who clicks to select days and watches visual response understands the model experientially.

evidence.quote: Guest: 'So you said you were with straight easy or straight lease?' She registered AND placed a bid without correctly remembering the platform name.
evidence.insight: Brand name confusion signals zero comprehension. Visual brand mark must be prominent in primer (logo, accent color, distinctive calendar visual style) to create recognition.

colors: accent-light for calendar cell hover states
typography: serif 24px medium for headline 'How Split Lease Works'
mono 20px semibold for cost calculation numbers
spacing: xl between calendar and cost calculation
new_tokens_needed: interaction-feedback-glow (accent color at 20% opacity for hover states)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text and interactive elements. Calendar day labels must meet 4.5:1 contrast. Selected days use accent green background with white text providing 5.2:1 contrast. Disabled bid button at 50% opacity still maintains 3.0:1 contrast (acceptable for disabled state). Active bid button meets 4.5:1 minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Calendar dominates visually (largest element, most colorful, central position). Headline creates entry point (serif 24px draws eye). Cost calculation provides validation (mono font signals precision, positioned directly below calendar to create causal relationship). Call-to-action button becomes visually prominent only after interaction complete (full opacity accent green vs muted disabled state).
elements.brand_alignment: Warm through spacious layout and rounded calendar cells (md radius). Confident through interactive demonstration rather than passive reading. Premium-accessible through serif headline (elegant) paired with sans body text (approachable). Relentless personalization: Calendar pre-fills with guest's stated schedule if already provided, showing system remembers their input.

elements.title: Decision-Density Visual Scaling
elements.problem: Zella received either too little information (no listings shown) or too much complexity at wrong time (landlord economics during budget discussion). Information density must match visual real estate and decision requirements. Search phase needs medium-density cards for scanning. Evaluation phase needs high-density detail for deciding. Proposal phase needs minimal, decision-critical elements only. Visual design must create clear density tiers through typography size, spacing, and color intensity.
elements.solution: Create three visual density patterns: (1) Search cards: 280px × 320px, single property photo (240px height), 3-4 data points in sans 14px (price, location, dates), generous spacing (md throughout). (2) Evaluation view: Full-width layout, photo gallery (480px height), 15-20 data points organized in 3-column grid, smaller typography (sans 13px for details), tighter spacing (sm). (3) Proposal form: Narrow column (400px max-width), 3-5 input fields with large labels (sans 16px medium), spacious layout (lg spacing) to reduce cognitive load. Use color intensity to signal density: Search cards use muted colors (ink-soft for secondary info), evaluation uses full contrast (ink for all details), proposal uses high contrast (ink-soft for labels, ink for input values).

evidence.quote: Search phase: Maximum 5-7 data points per listing card. Evaluation phase: Maximum 20-25 data points organized in scannable sections. Proposal: Maximum 3-5 data points requiring active decision.
evidence.insight: Visual density must be constrained and purposeful. More information ≠ better decision. Visual design enforces information limits through physical space allocation.

evidence.quote: Guest receives landlord economics (too much detail) without receiving her own outcome range (too little).
evidence.insight: Wrong density for context. Visual design must hide platform mechanics and show guest outcomes. Use progressive disclosure: link to 'How pricing works' rather than inline explanation.

colors: border for card edges and dividers
typography: sans 16px semibold for card titles and prices
sans 14px regular for search card data
sans 13px regular for evaluation detail data
mono 14px regular for precise values (prices, dates)
spacing: Search cards: md padding, sm between data points
Evaluation: lg section padding, sm between detail rows
Proposal: xl form padding, md between input fields

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all primary information. Search cards: price and location must meet 4.5:1 contrast (ink on surface). Secondary details can use ink-soft (7.5:1) to create visual hierarchy without sacrificing legibility. Evaluation view: all data points must meet 4.5:1 minimum. Proposal form: labels in ink-soft (7.5:1), input values in ink (14.6:1) for maximum clarity.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Photo leads in search cards (top position, 75% of card height), data supports below. Price uses mono font and larger size (16px semibold) to create primary focus point. In evaluation, photo gallery leads (top third of viewport), details organized in scannable 3-column grid (middle third), actions/CTA bottom third. Proposal form: single-column center-aligned creates focus, no competing elements visible.
elements.brand_alignment: Confident through appropriate density: Not overwhelming with detail, not starving of information. Warm through generous spacing in high-stakes decisions (proposal form). Premium-accessible through photo-led design (beautiful imagery creates aspiration) paired with clear data (transparency creates trust).

elements.title: Timeline Agency Visualization
elements.problem: The agent told Zella matching would take 'a couple of weeks' without visual timeline validation or agency indicators. Timeline anxiety compounds process uncertainty. Guest needs to see typical timelines, current progress, and actions they can take to maintain momentum. Pure text timeline information gets ignored—visual progress indicators create tangible sense of movement.
elements.solution: Create horizontal timeline progress bar showing current phase and expected duration with visual markers. Bar uses three colors: accent for completed segments, accent-light for current phase, ink-ghost for upcoming phases. Above bar, show timestamp labels in mono 12px ('Proposal sent 2 hrs ago', 'Response expected in 24 hrs'). Below bar, show optional agency actions as small accent-colored buttons ('Send 2 more proposals to speed up booking'). Use subtle animation (300ms ease-out) when progress advances to create moment of delight and accomplishment. Timeline persists as sticky header element (z-index 500) so guest always sees progress regardless of scroll position.

evidence.quote: Primary: Expected timeline with confidence range. Secondary: Actions guest can take to maintain/accelerate timeline. Tertiary: Progress indicators showing movement toward goal.
evidence.insight: Visual timeline must show all three: expectation (bar segments with labels), agency (action buttons below), progress (completed segments in accent color with animation on update).

evidence.quote: Agent: 'it will take me probably a couple of weeks to locate the mentioned individual'—vague timeline without context, agency, or progress visibility.
evidence.insight: Text timeline creates anxiety. Visual timeline creates orientation and control. Guest can glance at sticky header and know exactly where they stand.

typography: sans 12px medium for agency action buttons
spacing: Timeline bar: 8px height, md padding within container
md between bar and agency actions
new_tokens_needed: timeline-sticky-shadow (subtle shadow for sticky header depth)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text labels. Timeline bar segments must have clear visual distinction: accent (#2d5a3d) vs accent-light (#e8f0eb) vs ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) creates sufficient contrast for status differentiation. Timestamp labels in mono 12px must meet 4.5:1 contrast (use ink, not ink-muted). Agency action buttons meet 4.5:1 contrast in default state.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Timeline bar is primary visual element (horizontal center, full width minus container padding). Timestamp labels float above (small, mono font signals precision). Agency actions support below (small buttons, subtle, available but not demanding). Sticky positioning keeps timeline visible during scroll, reinforcing progress awareness throughout session.
elements.brand_alignment: Confident through transparency: Guest always knows where they are. Premium-accessible through subtle animation (delight without distraction). Relentless personalization: Timeline shows guest's specific timestamps ('your proposal sent 2 hrs ago') not generic phases. Fast response through sticky positioning and instant visibility.

elements.title: Expectation Calibration Visual Contrast
elements.problem: Zella entered with wrong expectations (thought she was speaking to one host, didn't understand platform nature). Visual design must proactively show how Split Lease differs from traditional rentals before misconceptions form. Pure text comparisons get skipped—visual contrast creates memorable differentiation and sets accurate expectations.
elements.solution: Create side-by-side visual comparison card in discovery phase: 'Traditional Rental' (left, shown in muted ink-soft colors) vs 'Split Lease' (right, shown in accent colors). Use simple iconography (24px icons) with short labels: Traditional shows single person icon + full calendar + high price tag. Split Lease shows two person icons + split calendar (guest days in accent, co-tenant days in surface-warm) + lower price tag. Keep visual extremely simple (3 comparison points max) and use generous spacing (xl) to avoid overwhelm. Positioning: discovery phase hero section, before any commitment actions.

evidence.quote: Primary: What guest will experience that differs from traditional rental expectations. Use simple comparative language ('Different from traditional rentals') rather than absolute descriptions.
evidence.insight: Visual comparison creates instant orientation. Guest sees in one glance what makes this different and whether it fits their needs.

evidence.quote: Guest: 'how close as YOUR place to CCNY?' Agent: 'I work for split lease.' Guest assumes single landlord, not platform.
evidence.insight: Mental model mismatch creates confusion throughout journey. Visual contrast must establish correct model (platform connecting multiple properties, multiple guests) immediately.

typography: serif 20px medium for 'Traditional Rental' and 'Split Lease' labels
sans 14px regular for comparison point labels
spacing: xl between left and right comparison sides
lg between comparison points within each side
new_tokens_needed: comparison-divider (1px border color vertical line between sides)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text. Traditional rental side in ink-soft (#4a4640) provides 7.5:1 contrast and creates visual de-emphasis. Split Lease side in accent (#2d5a3d) provides 4.7:1 contrast and draws attention. Price numbers in mono font must meet 4.5:1 minimum. Icons use 2px stroke width for clarity.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Split Lease side (right) should be slightly larger and more colorful to create visual bias toward the new model while still showing comparison fairly. Vertical center alignment of comparison points creates scannable reading pattern. Divider line between sides creates clear boundary without harsh separation (1px border color, subtle).
elements.brand_alignment: Confident through direct comparison rather than avoiding traditional rental mention. Warm through color choice (accent green vs harsh competitive red). Premium-accessible through balanced presentation (acknowledging alternatives exist while highlighting differentiation). Trustworthy through transparency (not hiding that this is different, celebrating it).
